Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2018 06:45PM shadylady1 wrote: I am 8 years out from chemo and my WBC is still on the low end. I haven’t had any issues as a result.
Posts.Title: WBC still low, seven months after finishing chemo sumomo CBK

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2014 09:02AM shadylady1 wrote: Hi Lynette! I had the same thing after radiation and while on Tamoxifen. My radiologist watched them for a year and I was checked every 6 months. She thought the calcifications were damage from radiation. When they started growing, she biopsied them and it was nothing. It's just using an X-ray or 3d imagery rather than ultrasound. I have had both. Not much difference but it can be due to the location of the calcifications. Wishing you the best! Praying for benign results!
Posts.Title: New microcalcifications found, stereotactic scheduled ðŸ˜• Lynette73 RaiderGirl

Best of luck to you!Â

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 09:09PM shadylady1 wrote: Hi Tina!Â  I am going to attend the conference in DC as well on the 17th!Â  I live in Richmond.Â  Are you staying at the Four Seasons?Â  I am heading up on Friday after work and staying at the Westin in Georgetown.Â  I had a lumpectomy and I understand the first half is about breast reconstruction.Â  I am really looking forward to the lymphedema section which is the second half!Â  Hope to meet you!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 09:25PM shadylady1 wrote: Becky - I have a ton of weight to lose and I am so glad to hear that losing weight has helped you so much.Â  I am actually in Georgetown (Washington, D.C.) and I am attending Dr. Marga's seminar at the Four Seasons tomorrow.Â  The afternoon dicussion is related to lymph node transplant surgery. I need to lose 150 lbs but I work out 3 times a week, lift weights (40-50 pounds in my arms and a lot more in my legs) and can knock out cardio - 30 minutes on the bike without difficulty.Â  I have gained 80 pounds since treatment and I really need to get my act together.Â  The idea that my lymphedema can significantly improve (mine is stage 2) by losing weight is certainly the most motivation I have had in a long time!Â  Thank you for sharing!Â  Emily
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: May 30, 2014 02:58AM shadylady1 wrote: I have a biopsy scheduled a week from today and I am petrified.Â  Same side as my cancer.Â  The radiologist initially thought the microcalcifications were due to radiation damage but they have grown so she now wants to biopsy them after a year of watching.Â  I have gained 130 pounds since I was diagnosed.Â  I feel completely out of control as if I have a backpack on filled with explosives and someone else has the detonator.Â  She told me if I didn't have this history of breast cancer, she wouldn't even do a biopsy.Â  I have been taking Tamoxifen religiously for 3 1/2 years.Â  I will be super pissed if this f'in cancer is back after taking that medication and dealing with the side effects.Â  If it isn't working, where else is the cancer?Â  I am scared shitless!
Posts.Title: Cancer, rinse, repeat ? bluewillowskys AlexaP

Posts.Content: shadylady1 wrote: I was treated for Lymphedema a little over a year ago.Â  I have it in my left arm and left breast.Â  I wear compresion garments.Â  A little over a month ago I experienced swelling regardless of whether I wrap at night, wear the compression bra and sleeve and elevate it, etc. so I begin treatment again on Monday.Â  The one thing I have noticed is that my "good" breast and the chest wall feel swollen.Â  I had my mammogram 5 moths ago and myÂ annual breat MRI is scheduled inÂ 3 weeks.Â  Â I am 45 but have been in chemopause for over a year and I am being switched from Tamoxifen (which I have been off of for a month) to an AI.Â  I even feel a little soreness in my right arm.Â  Has anyone else experienced this?Â  I know my left arm and breast are swollen and have been this way for a month but I am wondering if this tenderness that I am experiencing on the right side is related to the lymphedema?Â  Thank you! I have also gained 60 pounds since treatment which doesn't help the lymphedema situation..Â  Dx 5/13/2010, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 3/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Surgery 6/3/2010 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 7/8/2010 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 11/14/2010 Whole-breast: Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 12/31/2010 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lymphedema in chest wall on "good" side shadylady1 Binney4

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 08:49PM shadylady1 wrote: Sherry - will you be taking Tamoxifen?Â  I was looking at your profile and it seems we are similar in node status, hormone receptors,etc.Â  I thought you had IDC which represents 80% of all breast cancers.Â Â  My oncologist was very positive about my prognosis using Adjuvant and I would think you wouldÂ have a positive prognosis as well.Â  As hard as it is and as worried as I am about recurrence/mets, I try to remind myself thatÂ thereÂ areÂ many clinical trials currently in progress. I pray that in our lifetime they get the breast cancer vaccineÂ successfully through the clinical trials and that we will benefit from it!Â  I have lost friends to this disease as well as have friends who are currently Stage IV.Â  I have to keep my hope up (as hard as that is on some days) for all of us. It is a daily struggle for me.Â  I wish you all the best and I pray for peace for all of us.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 09:06PM shadylady1 wrote: Sherry - good luck with your bone scan!Â  I haven't had one yet. Â I can totally relate to feeling decrepit.Â  When I get out of bed in the morning it takes a while for my body to warm up. I feel like I am 80 but I understand it will take a year or so to get back to "normal".Â  I can't imagine what Tamox is going to do me once I start that at the end of the year.Â  I am only 3 weeks from my last chemo but I see a little hair growing back on my head.Â  Of course I am using a magnifying glass but it gives me hope.Â  No such luck in the eyelashes/eyebrows area.Â

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 11:08PM shadylady1 wrote: Count me in with the joint pain.Â  I finished chemo 3 weeks ago and I am stiff with muscle soreness and aching joints amongst other things like pitting edema.Â  It's hard for me to get up sometimes!Â  I feel like I have aged 40 years!Â  I haven't taken anything for it yet.Â Has anyone found any meds that help?Â  I may try to take some Aleve.Â  I do know that when I was on the steroids the day before and the day after chemo that the joint pain did diminish.Â Â I hope you all feel better soon!

Posts.Content: shadylady1 wrote: Hi everyone!Â  I hope you all are well!Â  I received my Flexitouch in the mail Tuesday.Â  The rep was supposed to come last night for training but she had to reschedule.Â  I had been using one in the PT's office and I was normally the one who put it on and adjusted it before treatment so I feel somewhat familiar with the equipment.Â  The question I have is for those who use these, do you see results right away?Â  I only used it twice a week at the PT's office, not every day.Â  Also, do you take it all apart to store it?Â  I would hate to have to put this thing together every time (the trunk and arm pieces).Â  I saw from Binney's prior post that she stores hers under the bed in a storage box so I am headed to Walmart after work.Â  Thanks in advance for any insight!Â  Em Dx 5/13/2010, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 3/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Surgery 6/3/2010 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 7/8/2010 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 11/14/2010 Whole-breast: Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 12/31/2010 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2010 04:36PM shadylady1 wrote: Hi Gina!Â  Doing great!Â  Just had my 5th chemo today and so far so good!Â  I usually start feeling it on Monday which is when I get the Neulasta shot.Â  The lymphedema clinic has really been helping me and I should receive my compression bra on Tuesday.Â  I am interested to see the difference between the new bra and the sports bras I have been wearing.Â  At this point they are trying to get the swelling down (it isn't too bad) before they order the compression sleeve.Â  I will be using it for exercise, gardening, etc.Â  I too am trying not to carry anything on the left side and I can certainly feel the muscles on the right side groaning!Â  Of course, I am the fool who wants to carry everything in from the car at once so I need to adjust that a little....Â  Hope you have a wonderful weekend!Â  Emily.Â

Posts.Content: shadylady1 wrote: I am currently seeing my PT again for MLD after experiencing some swelling in my left arm and trunk that wasn't resolving as it usually did.Â  I am noticing that my breasts, armpit (good side) and my sternum are sore as it used to be before I got my period.Â  Just really tender.Â  Has anyone else ever experienced this?Â  She is fantastic and uses a very light touch so it isn't a technique issue.Â  Just curious to see what others have experienced.Â  I haven't had a period in almost 2 years since my first chemo treatment and I am 45. Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 04:56AM shadylady1 wrote: My radiologist told me that I will have to have an annual breast MRI because my breasts are complicated.Â  I have had 2 breast MRI's in the last 6 months.Â  The second one was just 2 weeks ago.Â  The next test will be a mammogram one year from diagnosis.Â  My cancer was diagnosed from a mammogram.Â  My insurance covered my MRI's because I was told that once I was diagnosed with breast CA, I am now deemed "high risk".Â  I am sorry if this isn't helpful.Â  Have you spoken with your radiologist?Â  Since they are the ones who have to read them (not the oncologist) pehaps they could give you a better idea of what is best for you.Â
